dialogues.text: 32 9/30/03 MM revs. (cherry) 32.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Because I say so. Max grips the steering wheel. Vincent has plastic ties an proceeds quickly and efficiently to bind Max's hands to t steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cab's a disgrace. No wonder the cops pulled you over. On the way out of the car...

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCH RADIO, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Max? Max? You out there, you son of a bitch? Vincent looks to Max...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Who...is that?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Lenny, my dispatcher.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know you're out there! Answer the goddamn call!

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: What happens if you don't?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: He'll keep calling.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Max? Answer! Vincent reaches across Max, pulls the mike off the dash, it up to Max's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Don't blow it. Max nods. Vincent thumbs the toggle.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah? Lenny? It's me.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got off the phone with the cops. A desk sergeant called to check you brought the cab in... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 9/14/03 MM revs. (cherry) 33.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence as Lenny waits for a reaction. Max and Vincent tr look. Vincent shrugs, thumbs the toggle. Say something.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yeah? So?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So? So, aside from I hate talking to cops, they tell me you crashed the goddamn cab?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: It got crashed! I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do I care what, where or why? You're payin'!

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: It was an accident. You're not liable. (Tell him.)

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: It was an accident. I'm not liable.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bullshit! I'm making you liable! It's comin' outta your goddamn pocket... Vincent stares at Max, expecting him to respond.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Tell him to stick the cab up his fat ass.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I can't do that. He's the Man.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I need the job.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You still there? I'm talking to you! Max? Max? Vincent abruptly puts the mike to his mouth, thumbs the t (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 9/14/03 MM revs. (cherry) (3)

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He's not paying you a damn thing! 33A. 32 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 9/30/03 MM revs. (cherry) 34.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? Vincent glances up, tilts the visor down to see Annie's b card.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Richard Riccardo, Assistant U.S. Attorney. A passenger in this taxicab, and I'm reporting you to the DMV...

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (beat) Let's not get excited.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Not excited? How am I supposed to not get excited, listening to you try to extort a working man? You know goddamn well your collision policy and general liability umbrella would cover the damages. What are you trying to pull, you sarcastic prick?

dialogues.speaker: LENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm just tryin' to...to...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Tell it to him. (shifts the mike) Tell him he's an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (hesitates) You're an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Tell him next time he pulls any shit, you're gonna stick this yellow cab up his fat ass.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Next time you pull any shit, I'm gonna stick this yellow cab up your fat ass. Vincent clicks off, hangs up the mike. Looks at Max. Beat. Max, taped to the steering wheel, nods.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (smiles) Don't wait up, hon. I gotta work late. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 9/24/03 MM revs. (green) 34A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He grabs the ignition keys, shuts Max's door, strolls awa (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: 32D
dialogues.text: 10/2/03 MM revs. (tan) 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Max watches in the sideview mirror as Vincent vanishes in building. Max is left alone, trapped in his own cab in the alley. Max jerks and strains against the duct tape, trying to fr hands. He gives up, breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The overweight LAWYER, SYLVESTER CLARKE, who we saw on Vi P.C., separates from two girls and a second man, all watc TV, to answer a phone...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVESTER CLARKE
dialogues.text: He identify himself? (beat) Sure. Let him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in shades leaves the Hotel Security and enters the elevat Meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crosses towards the front door.

dialogues.speaker: ON MAX 32D
dialogues.text: He glances in the sideview, wondering where Vincent is, straining for a glimpse. Nothing. Just darkness back there... Mind racing...

dialogues.speaker: CAB
dialogues.text: The street traffic's distant; nobody's around.

dialogues.speaker: A GUN
dialogues.text: Max thrashes wildly against the duct tape, screaming with frustration. He starts head-butting the car horn...

dialogues.speaker: BEEEEEP
dialogues.text: He raises his head, checking the street traffic a quarter away. No one on the sidewalk takes notice of Max's cab. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee eK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/2/03 MM revs. (tan) 35A.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck me. He shifts low on the seat, getting his knee under the das He slams his knee up, hitting the RED EMERGENCY LIGHT BUT concealed there. EMERGENCY STROBES START FLASHING at the and rear of the car... .»+-and still nobody notices.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTMAS TREE OVER HERE.
dialogues.text: He throws a look to the sideview mirror, sweaty and tense knowing he's out of time. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 36.

dialogues.speaker: THE SIDEVIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: IN WHICH WE SEE Max's reflected eyes. Seconds ticking breathlessly away as he struggles... He head butts the horn again. BEEP-BEEP. BEEEEP. Flashers horn! MEANWHILE the ANGLE SHIFTS in the mirror, leaving Max's e bringing into view the building and the penthouse at the we SEE... ...TWO SILENT MUZZLE FLASHES light up the windows like flashbulbs going off. Another death. Then A THIRD FLASH.. nothing. Lights out. Meanwhile...

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh shit, oh shit, oh shit. He is head-butting the horn. BEEEEP. BEEP-BEEP. And he ch the mirror. This time when he looks, he sees... YOUNG WHITE GUYS. 20-25. They were on the sidewalk. Now t detour into the alley and approach the distressed cab fro back, shielding their eyes from Max's flashing lights.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, thank God! Hey, hey, man, help me out here!

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: Yo, whassup?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (fast, stumbling) I got my, my hands taped to the steering wheel, here, by this guy, who's taped me in the car, 'cause he's up in the building somewhere... CLOSER, now, the four are in baggies, hoodies and tattooe lightning bolts on their necks, swastikas on chests, one "5150" tattooed on his shaven eyebrow (police code for emotionally disturbed)...

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: You all trapped in there and shit?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: ...yeah, he's coming back. Hurry. Get me loose so I can call the cops... WHITE GUY #1 nods...and pulls a chromed .380 and points i Max. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9/22/03 MM revs. (yellow) 36A.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: Fuck that, man, gimme your wallet. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9/22/03 MM revs. (yellow) 37.

dialogues.speaker: 32D CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The others have walked off down the alley, laughing. One a beer bottle that smashes. Utter disbelief from Max...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: I will fuck you up! Hand it over.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (beat) My hands are taped to the damn steering wheel! It takes a moment for WHITE GUY #1 to process this. He st the window, presses the .380 against Max's cheek. It's ut terrifying, everything happening fast:

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-.don't shoot me, don't shoot me...

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: Then get your ass up, up... Max pulls himself up by the steering wheel, trying to get butt off the seat to give the Young Man access. The White #1 gropes for Max's back pocket, trying to get the wallet pressing the gun to his face, the other guys down the all turn the corner. White Guy #1 pulls Max's wallet, pockets it... ..-and pauses, seeing Vincent's briefcase on the back sea He yanks open the back door, grabs Vincent's briefcase, t walks off after his friends. White Guys #3 and #4 turned corner. White Guy #2 lingers. Max, still taped, is shaken. He can't believe what happen He looks through the windshield at...

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: .».-walking off, cocky as hell, about to vanish into the

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yo' homie... White Guy #1 turns, to see the silhouette of Vincent. He his .380 side-handed, like he sees gangsters do on MTV. W Guy #2 joins him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/4/03 MM revs. (blue) 38.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (even) That my briefcase...? White Guy #1 approaches Vincent from the front...#2 from Vincent's left.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: May-be. And what the fuck else you got? He closes on Vincent with the .380, held high and on the Vincent's left slams aside #1's .380. Draws and FIRES fro hip, putting TWO ROUNDS into #1. HAMMERS-ON TWO ROUNDS to sternum, pivots. ONE to the head of #2. All in 1.6 second White Guy #2, falling backwards, is dead before he hits t ground. #1 never saw it coming. Vincent picks up his case retrieves something from #1's pocket, puts one more into head of #1 on the way back to the cab... ...where Max saw it all. Frozen in horror. Astonished. The rear door opens. Vincent hefts his briefcase into the seat. He gets into the front. Vincent sits for a moment, staring off, not looking at Ma Maybe ready to kill him. Vincent raises something into view. Max's wallet. He toss in Max's lap. Vincent flicks his hand. CLICK-CLACK, a Reeves folding hu in dull metal, razor sharp...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: (quietly) Where's the button? Under the dash?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (dry whisper) Yeah. Vincent leans over and slices the plastic tie, freeing Ma hands. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You mind turning it off? Max doesn't move for a moment, then reaches under the das turns off the strobes.  33

dialogues.speaker: 33A
dialogues.text: 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent in the back seat. (Juxtapose to a different conti Through the side window, we see Crenshaw Boulevard barber music shops. We're stopped for a light.) Max is shell-sho

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Another collateral.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Collateral damage. People in the wrong place at the wrong time. (meets Max's gaze) And you? You attract attention? You are gonna get people killed who didn't need to be. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm low on gas...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Pull in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pulls by.

dialogues.speaker: TIME-LAPSE
dialogues.text: race by. WIDEN. SEE Max filling up the taxi. Vincent is positioned off the right rear corner from where he is lin sight to everything. His affect is flat, distant. Max has witnessed violent death and the full, lethal capabilities Vincent. Neither say a word...until softly...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Vincent?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Yes, Max?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Am I collateral? Pause. A long one.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I haven't decided. Max is silent. Absorbing this. Vincent checks his watch. Unexpectedly, his mood changes up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod)

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But, hey! New news. We are ahead of schedule.

dialogues.speaker: 33A
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 40. CONTINUED: (2) 33a

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: We got time to kill. (fast change-down) You like jazz?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm...what? Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Jazz.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Not that much.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Guy told me about a place off Crenshaw. Leimert Park. All the West Coast greats played there. Dexter Gordon, Thelonious Monk, Chet Baker. Like that... (off Max's look) Buy you a drink. Expand your horizons... Max doesn't get Vincent's mood up-change. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: COPS and FORENSIC TECHNICIANS. In the midst of it all is: Ray Fanning. He wears his badge, visibly, now. We find hi turning as his superior, RICHARD WEIDNER, 50-ish, is ente the crime scene.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: ...this informant of yours, what's his name, Ramone?

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Ramone Gallardo. Supposed to take him for a drink. I come here, find this.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: You been working him?

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Four months...a low-level player, he's been feeding me stuff on Felix. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 10/4/03 MM revs. (blue)

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: Reyes-Torrena? Forget Felix. Feds are all over that. They don't want us anywhere near it. 40A. 34 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 41.

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Since when is the LAPD working for the Feeb? (points up) Besides, Ramone flew out a window. My C.I. flew out a window, he's got Felix's handprints on his ass. Yes? That makes it ours.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: (as if to a child) Where's the homicide, Ray? Where's a body? All we got is glass... He spreads his hands at the alley floor in a gesture that "show me something besides glass."

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CRIMINALIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And blood...

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CRIMINALIST
dialogues.text: (off looks) .--blood...down here...in the glass...here's some more... A FEMALE CRIMINALIST (SID) examines the alley floor with and a handheld BLACKLIGHT WAND, picking out dark patterns

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE CRIMINALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...small splatter patterns here...all over there... SHINING FLASHLIGHTS pick out blood on the alley wall. Fan steps to where the cab was parked, stands in the middle o blank spot surrounded by the glass, points down:

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Ramone flew out the window. Went splat. Here's the glass. (beat) Then some tires rolled over it.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: How's that spell homicide? Maybe he jumped.

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Sure. He's depressed. So he jumps four stories out a window onto his head. (mimics) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 41A.

dialogues.speaker: FANNING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Wow, that feels better!" Picks himself up. "Now, I think I'll go on with the rest of my day..."

dialogues.speaker: PLAINCLOTHES COP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from above) Ray! Catch! Two uniformed cops have approached. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 42.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Weidner and Fanning glance up. A PLAINCLOTHES COP is lean out of Ramone's broken window, dangling a clear plastic b He drops it. It comes sailing down... ..-right into Fanning's grasp. He glances down at it, sho to Weidner...

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON WEIDNER
dialogues.text: ..-revealing two spent .45 cal. shell casings in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: (switches) So, who's got what? Any witnesses? We been knocking on doors?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Old guy across the street, lives above the deli? Says he saw a cab parked here earlier tonight. There were two guys working under the hood.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: Description. What did he see?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: "Kinda" saw...guy's got glasses like coke bottles.

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Did he "see" it or did his seeing eye dog see it?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Late-model four-door Ford. Yellow or orange. (off Fanning's look) Maybe it was a taxi cab.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: Four thousand taxis in LA County. (beat) What else...? That's it. Uniforms go back to work. Photographer shows. doesn't know what to shoot. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 10/11/03 MM revs. (goldenrod) 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Fanning, lost in thought...

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: Remember fall, 2001? That Bay Area deal? Oakland. Cabbie drove around all night. Killed three people...

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: Then he flipped out, put the gun to his head. So what?

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: So the Oakland PD detective, whatshisname, never bought it.

dialogues.speaker: WEIDNER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FANNING
dialogues.text: The Cabbie had no criminal record. No history of mental illness. Pops three people, then himself? And the victims weren't random. Two were involved in some pharmaceuticals scam... (off Weidner's look) Anyway, the detective always thought there was somebody else in that cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and elegant - in an early '60's modern jazz kind of with a low ceiling, small tables, leatherette booths, his soaked into the walls. A BLACK MAN in his late 50's, DANI playing a muted trumpet on stage with a QUARTET. CUSTOMERS are few, clustered at small tables or at a few leather booths. The walls are lined with great FRAMED PHO jazz icons. At one table, we find Vincent and Max. Vincent about the music... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 10/4/03 MM revs. (blue) 44. 35

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: ...a little '60's, early Miles thing happening...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I never learned to listen to jazz.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You don't learn to listen...anymore than you learn to breathe. Open your ears. Vincent's attention's focused on the music.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I get a beat. I don't really hear a melody...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: ..-he's off the melody, behind the notes. Outside what's expected. Improvising off impulse. Kind of like tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Like tonight?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) This is nothing, if not "What's next? Right now. In the moment." (beat) There's people...ten years from now? Same job, same place, same shit. Everything the same; keepin' it safe. Over and over and over and over... (beat) "Ten years from now?" Man, you don't know where you'll be...ten minutes from now...tonight. (beat; re: saxophonist) That's what he's saying. Open your ears. You'll hear it...in his “dialoguing" with the trumpet... The WAITRESS arrives, an Asian woman with a tray of drink

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: ‘Nother Vodka tonic, hon? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee eK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HH HH HH HH HH HH HK  35 10/4/03 MM revs.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: And one for my friend. (indicates stage) Who's on the tenor sax? (blue) 45. 35 be so kind

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: That's Daniel, baby, he's the owner.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: He is terrific. Would you as to invite him over after his set? I gotta buy him a drink.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Sure thing, darlin'... Vincent gives her a radiant smile and into her apron as she leaves... tucks a twenty dollar bill

dialogues.speaker: TIMECUT
dialogues.text: ..-and we find Daniel sharing more than a few drinks with Vincent and Max, them.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: the place almost closed. Just the three of ...I was a young cat back then, about nineteen, bussin' tables. Right here. Didn't pay but shit, but that wasn't the point. Being around the music, that was the thing. And I was. Take this one night...July 22, 1964...who walks in. Mr. Louis Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You're kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Right through those doors. The man himself.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: He was in town playing two gigs a night at the Coconut Grove in the Ambassador Hotel... After his last set, he decides to come on down to South Central to hang with his people. That's how he was, you see. Never forgot who we was. all that? Meant nothin', could blow that horn. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money and fame an' long as he (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So before you know it, he's up on that stage, doin' his thing.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Was it great? Better than great, it had to be...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Like Winton Marsalis says, it was pure, spiritual essence. Louis was playing. God was smiling.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: You heard Armstrong play live. I've never been this jealous. You get to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Did better'n that. Vincent gives him a questioning look. Daniel smiles, rais hands, mimes blowing a trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my, yes.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: C'mon...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Fella owned this place back then, cat named Dix Dwyer, he let slip to Louis that I played. So Pops, he just waves me right up. My heart about stopped. But I got up there all the same, and we played for nearly twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Unbelievable... (to Max) ...you hearing this? Max is drawn into the story in spite of himself:

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: How'd you do?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: How do you think? You ain't shit when you playing next to Louis Armstrong. But, Dippermouth, he was kind. He could see me trying. He carried my ass as best he could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 his

dialogues.speaker: D
dialogues.text: 35 10/4/03 MM revs. (blue) 47.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Remember what you played?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Most vividly. (ticking them off) "Potato Head Blues," "Sleepy Time Down South..." (laughs) ...then Pops laid some "Cornet Chop Suey" on me, and left me in the dust like a whipped dog.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Whipped dog?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Whipped dog on a wet night.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Crowd dig it?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: (smiles, nods) The crowd was most kind. (beat) I was born in 1945, but that was the moment of my conception. Right here in the used-to-be crowded room. Daniel picks up the bottle to freshen up their drinks...

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Crowds not here now?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, jazz ain't the draw it used to be.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: But the place looks great.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Only 'cause I got the wherewithal to finance keepin' it up on my own.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
